awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2021: Exploring host-parasite co-evolution under diverse selection pressures
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2021, Integrative Research Investigating the Rules of Life Governing Interactions Between Genomes, Environment and Phenotypes. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will contribute to the area of Rules of Life in innovative ways. The project will investigate the causes and consequences of the modes of parasite transmission, for both the parasite and the host. Parasites are an integral part of the natural world and have evolved multiple ways to use host resources, evade host immune defenses, and achieve transmission to new hosts. Previous research has primarily explored either vertical (e.g., parent to offspring) or horizontal (e.g., between adults of the same generation) parasite transmission. However, many parasites are transmitted both vertically and horizontally, and the role of these different transmission modes in host and parasite evolution are not well understood. Discovering the causes and consequences of diverse parasite transmission modes help us understand how parasites infect hosts, and could help inform disease control strategies. The Fellow will explore these questions using a stored grain pest, the Red Flour Beetle, and its naturally occurring protozoan parasite. In addition, the Fellow will: (1) increase the participation and retention of individuals from underrepresented groups in STEM through mentorship spanning multiple educational stages and (2) build relationships between researchers and stakeholders in agriculture. 

The Fellow will use an experimental evolution approach to coevolve beetle and parasite lines over multiple generations under horizontal, vertical, or mixed parasite transmission regimes. This project will assay host and parasite fitness trajectories as a function of transmission mode, and employ transcriptomic methods to identify the evolutionary consequences of parasite transmission mode for host immune system evolution. The fellow will develop a mathematical model using an adaptive dynamics framework to assess how epidemiological feedbacks associated with complex host-parasite interactions influence evolution of both the host immune phenotype and parasite virulence. The Fellow will work with Vanderbilt’s Collaborative for STEM Education and Outreach to develop a mentoring program focused on matching high school women of color interested in STEM with undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral women of color at Vanderbilt. In addition, the Fellow will collaborate with grain mill operators and the local integrated pest management office to discuss how the knowledge generated from this project can inform pest management strategies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overall, my research goal was to understand how parasite transmission mode influences the evolution of the host immune system using experimental evolution, transcriptomics, and mathematical modeling approaches. Additionally, I aimed to develop a mentorship program focused on matching women of color from local public high schools with undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral women of color at Vanderbilt University. My award commenced in September 2021 and ended in early November 2021 upon my acceptance of a full-time job offer.

During my two-month award period, I collaborated with Assistant Professor Ann Tate and graduate student Pi'ilani Noguchi to develop the conceptual modeling framework for the initial mathematical model. I began to gain an understanding of the traditional SIR modeling framework that would serve as a foundation for this work and learned how to create differential equations from the conceptual framework. I synthesized the progress of my research and outlined future steps in a written report for the Tate Lab, in the hope that a future researcher continues the project.

I collaborated with Vanderbilt's Collaborative for STEM Education and Outreach (CSEO) to develop the foundation for a mentorship program. First, I developed a mission statement for the program that provided an overview of the program and detailed the benefits to participants, responsibilities of both the mentor and mentee, guidance for forming mentorship groups, and suggested communication guidelines. Then, I created the curriculum for three sessions focused on effective listening, creating a mentoring network, and identifying needs and goals; I led three sessions using these materials with high school students from The School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt. I shared all of the program materials with the director of the CSEO, in the hope that a future researcher or educator continues the project.

In addition to my proposed projects, I also served as a mentor and editor to graduate students applying to the National Science Foundation's Graduate Research Fellowship Program.
